<@U3E2EEX38> >> why should I use `RealmRecyclerViewAdapter`?   Apart from auto updating fields

if you've read my article, you know why :stuck_out_tongue:
ye was gonna read it
<@U3E2EEX38> short answer is that you get a `RealmChangeListener` automatically added to the `RealmResults`, and this change listener calls `notifyDataSetChanged()`
as such when you write to the Realm on a background thread, the adapter gets automagically updated (no animations tho)
i see
thats nice
this is something you can also do manually, but why do it manually if Realm already gives an adapter that does the same thing you would :stuck_out_tongue:
is there a way to use this RealmChange Listner outisde of the recycler
Does it always call `notifyDataSetChanged()` or will it make effort to only call the more specialised methods?
I have an idea for something
<@U04TK850N> more specialized methods are a work in progress and will happen once Results integration is complete
so it is `notifyDataSetChanged()` currently
neat
<@U3E2EEX38> you can make a RealmChangeListener anywhere, just make sure you retain a field reference to your `RealmResults` somewhere
Well my idea was that when users add data to the database locally I can use the `RealmChangeListener` to notify the network sync to run
<@U3FTC3B55|osarez> has joined the channel
`RealmChangeListener` runs on any change to the RealmResults's underlying table
Sweet
I can use it
I am reading the docs

RealmChangeListener can be registered with a Realm, RealmResults or RealmObject to receive a notification about updates.
When registered against a Realm you'll get notified when a Realm instance has been updated. Register against a RealmResults or RealmObject to only get notified about changes to them.
I used them for a short time, but with MVP I dont like it
As the Presenter will have to know what a RealmResults is
And if youre using Rx, you can really easily implement your own anyway

> And if youre using Rx, you can really easily implement your own anyway 

I'm extremely skeptical of that, but go on

text: Thats now `Observable<List<SomeModel>>` being returned
I had a wild guess it involved `copyFromRealm()`
Any updates to realm and that fires again
Well yes
So either you have database logic sitting inside your view
Or you copy from realm and the view just handles a list
View now has no knowledge of realm, neither does the presenter
i think the next article i write for Realm will probably have to be about "flawed abstractions"
And Realm is only in your repositories now
talking about why `copyFromRealm()`, a method that copies from the Realm
doesn't really make sense when you're using a zero-copy database
Ok, so how do you test your presenter now that it knows about realm?
Or your view?
that's exactly what the article needs to be about :stuck_out_tongue:
Hahaha ok
the sad thing about realm is that it's instrumentation-test-only if you intend to test Realm itself
the gist of it is that you need an interface that wraps RealmResults, and an interface that wraps RealmChangeListener
and then you'll have an "observable result set"
which you can replace as a list in tests, because you can always change your repository
I think any solution that discards Realm's lazy-evaluation is a flawed one
might just be my own personal opinion though
/gif mind blown
I have no idea why I didnt even think of anything like that
probably because nobody has done it so far :stuck_out_tongue:
yeah, this is worth an article, lol

atm
not a fan of `*async().asObservable().filter().map(RealmResults::copyFromRealm)`
why?
because its assuming you *always* need a copy
which you likely do not
true
mostly because to obtain the list, you need to read all elements in the RealmResults from the Realm; and I'm pretty sure this mapping happens on the UI thread
youre going to spin up a lot of GC doing that
it does happen on the main thread unless you created a handler thread for realm to run in
<@U055GGAHS> if you can even get the GC up, considering you will have every element in the list
10 items?
Like I said later I will modify it
and most people don't bother with creating a looper-thread to create an "auto-update thread that Realm reads unmanaged objects from" :stuck_out_tongue:
im not sure why realm doenst default run on a thread other than the main thread
it's one of those things that i had entertained as a concept, but it just seems flawed in a zero-copy setup and therefore never bothered with lol
`findAllAsync()` executes the query on a background thread, and returns the RealmResults to the UI thread's Realm instance
so technically that's on a background thread
well it creates a warning if I dont use it
that method didnt come till 0.84
Realm works on background threads without a problem tho, you just need to open and close the instance on the background thread
right
that method `find*Async()` was totally unstable until 0.88.3 :stuck_out_tongue:
anyways, a solution that externalizes the query (which is pretty fast) to a background thread, then does all the reads and copying (which is kinda slow in batch) on the UI thread
for every single object in the result set, each time the database is written to; and not just the ones that are shown
seems wasteful :smile:
I've heard people using `copyFromRealm()` here and there, but I always say that the only place where it makes sense is when you pass the RealmObjects/RealmResults to GSON
otherwise it's a flawed way of thinking about Realm as a database <@U3E2EEX38> <@U055GGAHS>

text: The Google implementation is poorly documented.
By default ZXing is setup to launch their own app to do the scanning but you can take that code and work it into your own app so that you don't launch a different app for scanning.
Anyone have experience building a ContentProvider into an SDK?
mainly just want to know if I'm about to waste a lot of time trying something stupid
content providers are a form of IPC so how would you be wasting time (assuming you need IPC)
the first question I would ask, are you sure you need a content provider?

our company, Odd Networks, basically provides one common api for our client's to develop their various tv-connected and mobile applications against. so far the sdk is a wrapper for that api that deals with request building and parsing into POJOs, along with dealing with creating Accounts for their apps

i know they can make their own content providers and sync adapters and such, but would like to help that along if it makes sense to be opinionated about how that's done and whether it can be dynamic enough to fit just their authority (applicationId)
our client's develop apps, but we also do some of that internally, so it would be a nice-to-have for me if I can create/maintain one library
so you want to make an API they can optionally turn on when they bring in your library
right now we've built apps that make requests based on user interaction (start activity/fragment & make request)
so 3rd party apps can make API requests through your clients apps?
i'd like to be able to five them the option of syncing in the background, deep-linking, indexing, etc
you don't have to allow 3rd party access, do you?
think netflix or hbo
that's the type of data we provide
im not seeing the reason for using a content provider
content providers are ideal for providing IPC functionality but they can be used to simplify access to certain things like the file system or sqlite for example
but in both of those cases the idea is more that you can replace the provider transparently to the consumer but you can do that without using content providers so IPC is the real reason to use them
content loaders would be another reason to use content providers but thats kind of redundant if you arent planning on it being used as IPC
sorry if this is a dumb question but when you say IPC you mean sharing data between apps, right?
right
intents and AIDL are other forms of IPC on android
yeah that would not be necessary or desired, really
content provider is to share resources across processes
thats what I said :stuck_out_tongue:
sqlite database or file, i'd assume
FileUriExposedException is such a nuisance imo :open_mouth:
ah. bad assumption on my part. i thought a provider was necessary to make a syncadapter, but you can just make it a dummy provider
well the question is where you actually store the data
probably sqlite
and how you intend to share it
because if you intend to share it between apps, then sqlite + content provider is the best bet
no, not sharing between apps
I'm not entirely sure what you are doing in that database then :smile:
yeah i'm trying to think through if it's necessary to store things locally or not
on one hand it'd be nice to background sync new catalog things, but it isn't entirely necessary
Go offline for sure
Makes development easier for a start and there are many other benefits
You dont have to keep checking if you have an internet connection to make requests
If you decide to add offline later, it will be painful
<@U3FEVNR28|lorenzocamaione> has joined the channel
<@U3G4DLG4F|canadayj> has joined the channel
Hi there, I'm trying to build an app starting with the ribot boilerplate, and I'm using a viewPager (with fragments). I'm currently struggling with Dagger2 and the injection of my fragment presenters
Do I need to create another 'layer' of injection (like FragmentModule, component, context, with a new PerFragment scope) ?
Or can I use getActivity().activityComponent().inject(this) .
<@U200KUU56> it is completely up to you
i've done unscoped+singleton only, as well as subscoping
honestly, subscoping is more hassle :stuck_out_tongue:

>  can I use getActivity().activityComponent().inject(this) .

if it's in the activity, then I prefer to override `getSystemService()` and obtain the component via the context
and then `DaggerService.getComponent(context)`
I'm in the fragment, not the activity
and I want to inject the fragment to... something I guess (I'm just starting with dagger2)
and I can inject from anywhere ?
(sorry for my bad copy/paste)
getActivity().activityComponent().inject(this)  is for using in classes where you can't use constructor injection  like activitys
Yes
other wise use constructor injection
I'm in a fragment
then you need to either use getActivity().activityComponent().inject(this)
I cannot use constructor inejction
or
make a submodule for each fragment
which is better ?
It might be over kill but in my app I have a module/component for each View.
i personally just like to obtain unscoped presenters that i kill and restore on config change
with seperate scope
and otherwise everything else is singleton
in my new example project thing i am making a subcomponent for each
but wow is it a hassle XD
hmm
it's a question of preference
both works
I think its less hassle in the end
I have a template now for each view
:thumbsup:
I'm using the ribot boilerplate (<https://github.com/ribot/android-boilerplate>)

text: They implemented the injection for activities
but not for fragments, so I'm trying to replicate what they made (something like a generic injection system) for fragments
Well it really depends on the way you are structuring your app
if you have an activity per Feature then you most likely need a separate module for each activity
Some people do single activity plus many fragment
some people do single activity and many views
I'm using a viewPager, so I need to stick with fragments I guess
That's your choice
you do not have to
viewPager is just a viewGroup
I the case of single activity + many views, you implement the MVP models for each views ? Or do you have just one presenter ?
yes MVP each view
think of them as self contained
ok
it's very similar to what I have with fragments
but using DI I can get access to the singleton Network module but with ViewScope
Don't take anything I say as 100% right way/correct because I have been using java and Android for only since Oct
lol
... you made tremendous progress it seem !
I guess so :slightly_smiling_face:
I can't easily wrap my head around DI
I have used DI frameworks before, and I guarantee you have/are using DI already without realising it.
Its just that you have to learn how Dagger works
Yeah I guess so
<@U3FBYKKK5|a.esmaeili> has joined the channel
I'm struggling with the subcomponent/scope etc
You provide an Object to dagger
enter its dependencies
then when you want to use it
you can use constructor injection
so just specify the thing you made in @provides
and put @inject on the constructor
thats it
if its an activity then you have to use the DaggerBuilder
in that case you dont put @inject
there is also Field Injection and Method Injection
That probably made no sense
I'm not very good at explaining things sorry
No it was a good recap, but I knew the basics
Then you should be good
Sub components have to have seperate Scope
or Dagger wont even build
A subcomponent must be used in another component ?
Sorry I mean If you make a separate module but include another module as dependency
so Like I have MainViewModule
and the @provides are scoped
to @ViewScope
and the component has dependencies of another component
This module provides The model and presenter along with all dependecies
liek RestService
etc
then fragmentcomponent is a subcomponent ?
then in the module I can provide deps from the netmodule
I was wondering about @subcomponent
ahh
This is a separate component
I also had a separate scope for eachg view at one time
haha
I think thats overkill
haha alright
I still need to dive in some tutos
Reading code
is the best
I just download tonnes of projects and disect them
make sure I understand them
Well you seem motivated ! The problem is that I think the project needs to be 'humble' for me to dive in
A too big project is scary
hehe
It has to be big for me
Or think, whats the point
learn little by little, understand small projects before moving on to big ones
oh ye for sure, but most project examples that are on github are quite small
yeah that's true
If they are a complete mess I avoid them, I think you develop an intuition for good vs bad code, I still make a lot of mistakes though

Well thank you for your help, (and thanks to zhuinden, even though I did not understand all that you were saying :sweat_smile: )
Off to code now !

<@U3E2EEX38> > I also had a separate scope for eachg view at one time

a solution to create scopes per screen is to provide `Class<?> value();` parameter to the scope
it becomes different scopes
Oh nice thanks
Have you used RxBindings
I'm trying to make a Checkbox Observable
Scrap that
I did it
lol

<@U200KUU56>  > I was wondering about @subcomponent

`@Subcomponent` is just a different way to define a component dependency, but you create the subcomponent via a factory method inside the parent component
ahh I wondered also, I never had a need for it though
honestly in my current big projects i just have `@Singleton` and unscoped, and a single global injector, lol
LOL
I dont think theres anything wrong with that
but it can cause leaks
if you're not careful

text: I have a question about Runtime location permission. :slightly_smiling_face: Is it normal that ActivityCompat.checkSelfPermission(this, Manifest.permission.ACCES_FINE_LOCATION) is returniing PackageManager.PERMISSION_GRANTED even if the global device location setting is turned off?
<@U337FMTFE> Yes because permission is something different
If you go into you app's options on your phone and check under Permissions you will see a switch turned on
<@U0E72HWTX> then to check if location service is truly enabled for the app, I should use something like
Settings.Secure.getInt(context.getContentResolver(), Settings.Secure.LOCATION_MODE)
right?
in addition to the permission checking
Can't remember exact API for that but yes
Point is just because user granted a location permission doesnt mean he has locations services turned on, so you need to make sure of it

I once had a case with this. On Android 6.0 we had implemented some BLE scanning (this requires location service to be enabled since 6.0) but we were not checking if location service is enabled before every scan. People reported that BLE scan is not working because if you run it without location turned on it just won't return any result (wont crush or anything)
right.. So my current solution is to check first if location service is enabled then run ActivityCompat.checkSelfPermission to see if permission is granted
Thanks for the clarification <@U0E72HWTX> :slightly_smiling_face:
